text.p: These are the leading stories in Serbian and Montenegrin press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified them nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
- S E R B I A -
POLITIKA
- Spring sowing completed successfully on 2.29 hectares or 97 percent of the area planned, says Serbian government.
- Serbian government approves setting up of new shareholding company Telekom Srbija and adopts modalities for transfer of PTT Srbija rights to the new company to carry out its duties.
- Yugoslavia and Croatia sign a consular convention in Zagreb.
- Yugoslav-American business council meeting in New York. U.S. businessmen show interest in Yugoslav market.
- Yugoslav Prime Minister Radoje Kontic asks U.N. Security Council to extend mandate of U.N. troops on Prevlaka promontory which expires on July 15.
- Italian Altatrade and smeltery of Bor copper mines sign agreement on delivery of equiupment for brass foundry in Bor worth 1.45 million German marks.
- New Yugoslav president to be appointed at latest by July 25. Mandate of current president Zoran Lilic expires on June 25.
- Serbian police break coffee smuggling ring in northern town of Subotica.
NASA BORBA
- Foreign shareholders of BK Trade company fear the announced purchase of 49 percent stake of Serbia's PTT by Italy's STET will jeopardise their 20-year mobile telephony contract with PTT Srbije.
- Serbian Renewal Movement President Vuk Draskovic says his party will not ask for dismissal of Belgrade mayor Zoran Djindjic, will leave decision up to Djindjic's moral judgment.
- Belgrade Mayor Zoran Djindjic says he will not resign but will put the initative for his resignation up for discussion if 20 councillors sign it.
- Striking health workers to agree today with Serbian government on dynamics of wage payments.
- Increasing number of schools joining teachers' strike, 128 schools were on strike Tuesday and 117 schools in Vojvodina announce starting strike on June 2.
- Construction of railway line Bijeljina-Brcko-Samac to start in June, it was agreed by Belgrade transport institute Saobracajni Institut CIP and Bosnian Serb railways.
- Yugoslavia does not fulfil conditions for IMF membership, says German Ambassador in Belgrade Wilfried Gruber.
POLITIKA EKSPRES
- Defence ministry preparing amendments to army law under which compulsory 12-month army service to be served at 19 years instead of 21.
DNEVNI TELEGRAF
- Some 20,000 Yugoslav firms ready for bankruptcy according to the Institute for Market Research. At end of April 22,360 firms were insolvent.
- M O N T E N E G R O -
POBJEDA
- Montenegrin parliament forms its own committee for control of the security service.

- Spokesman of Montenegrin President Momir Bulatovic, Momcilo Stojanovic, reacts to Pobjeda interview of police minister Filip Vujanovic substantiating president Bulatovic's allegations that Vujanovic is not a man of his word.
- Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic visited the municipality of Kotor on Tuesday, stressed importance of Yugoslavia's integration into the international community. -- Belgrade newsroom +381 11 222 4305
